page.title: 08Local Superstitions
page.content: Many miners were superstitious. Miners would consider meeting a woman with a squint or leaving something at home as signs of ill-omen and would not go to work. If a shaft was to be sunk a sovereign would be placed on the lst sod and thrown to the crowd. On "calling days" the miners' wives would place tongs on the mantlepiece or put a cat in an unlit oven to ensure their men were allotted good jobs. Miners would not wash their back in case of weakening them. Fishermen would not go to sea if they saw a pib on Friday, and the word 'pig' is unlucky. The ill-omen can be cancelled by making a thumbs up gesture. Every day supersitions and customes include:not leaving a house by the same door unless a seat has been taken: not putting new shoes on a table; placing a poker on coals to encourage flames.
